comments:
This course introduces computation and data analysis using MATLAB - an
industry standard programming and visualization environment. The course covers the
fundamentals of computing including: variables, functions, flow control, iteration, and
recursion. These concepts are illustrated through examples and assignments which show
how computing is applied to various scientific and engineering problems. Examples are
drawn from the simulation of physical and chemical systems, the analysis of
experimental data, Monte Carlo numerical experiments, image and audio processing, and
control of sensors and actuators.
Overall, students thought that this course was a good introductory programming
course. However, for those with no prior programming experience, little extra help is
offered. Students were thrown blindly into the first few projects, and oftentimes those
with prior programming knowledge benefitted much more than those who had never been
exposed to it before.
Professor Dietz was seen as a good teacher, but some students wished that she did
a little more teaching in regards to the programming she expected her students to
complete. Dietz believes that “everyone is smart” and thus “capable of tackling the
challenges of programming and debugging,” but those with little prior experience had
difficulty following her teaching style.
Students appreciated the depth of knowledge they gained about MATLAB. The
projects for homework were apt, and many felt the tests were slightly biased toward those
who could write code faster. However, students thought this was a good course overall.

This course provides an introduction to computation and data analysis using
MATLAB, which is an industry standard programming and visualization environment.
The course covers the fundamentals of computing including variables, functions, flow
control, iteration and recursion. These concepts are illustrated through examples and
assignments which show how computing is applied to various scientific and engineering
problems. Examples are drawn from the simulation of physical and chemical systems, the
analysis of experimental data, Monte Carlo numerical experiments, image and audio
processing, and control of sensors and actuators. This course does not assume any prior
programming experience but makes use of basic concepts from calculus and Newtonian
physics.
Students for the most part enjoyed this course, despite it being time consuming.
Most students were satisfied with Professor Dietz. However, one student did note
that some of the debugging concepts were not taught clearly enough during lecture. They
found lab hours to be “helpful” in debugging code and completing the projects
throughout the semester.
This course was time-consuming and students found themselves spending a lot of
time with the TAs to debug their code and thoroughly finish their projects.
Fewer than eight student comments were submitted for this course.
